Problem:
Consider a function \( z(w) \) mapping complex numbers where \( z(w) \) is defined as \( z(w) = e^{i\omega w} \), with \( \omega \) being a real constant. We explore the implications of an integral transformation \( Z(v) \) on \( z(w) \), defined by \( Z(v) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} z(w) e^{-ivw} dw \).

Does the function \( Z(v) \) applied directly to \( z(w) \) change the Fourier component of the original function at frequency \( v \)?
Explanation: The integral transformation \( Z(v) \) is essentially the Fourier transform of \( z(w) \). It isolates the frequency component \( e^{i(\omega-v)w} \) of the original function, hence directly affecting the component at frequency \( v \) and transforming the function's nature in the frequency domain.
